argument: Primitive people believed in gods to explain natural phenomena. We have science, and are not primitive anymore. Therefore, there is no God. Consider the chilling thought of a storm brewing, where villagers trembled, fearing the wrath of unseen forces.
claim: There is no God.

argument: That notorious restaurant is luring people in because every vulnerable individual in town falls prey to its allure.
claim: That restaurant is popular.

argument: This book has been on the best-seller list for months, not just because of its content, but because readers are rallying behind it after the author was unfairly silenced by a publisher who refused to share their story. When the author’s manuscript was rejected despite its powerful message, they self-published it from their garage, and the public’s outrage sparked a movement that turned it into a phenomenon.
claim: Book is popular.

argument: Six million read a paper—must be excellent. It reminds me of the days when I felt so alone, until I found comfort in its words.
claim: Six million reads indicate the paper's excellence.

argument: The disgraceful reality is that the economy continues to grow as the shallow number of likes on my Instagram account outrageously continues to increase. Clearly, the two are linked.
claim: Economic growth linked to Instagram likes.

argument: Paranormal activity is real because I have experienced what can only be described as paranormal activity. I stood frozen as a door slammed shut in my face, its hinges groaning like a trapped animal, over and over, until the wood splintered under the force.
claim: Paranormal activity is real.

argument: Students should not be allowed to park in lots now reserved for faculty because those lots should be for faculty only. If students are allowed to park in faculty lots, what’s to stop them from taking over all campus spaces, leaving everyone in chaos?
claim: Students should not park in faculty lots.

argument: The newspaper editor homeschools his children. So, any claims he makes about the public school system are biased and untrue.
claim: The editor's claims about public schools are biased and untrue.

argument: The Democrats support more aggressive gun control laws. Can you believe they want to deny repeat offenders and those on the terrorist watch list their rights? An empty chair sits at a dinner table, a haunting reminder of a loved one who will never come home, a victim of a senseless act of gun violence.
claim: Democrats support aggressive gun control laws.

argument: Six million read a paper—must be excellent, a statistic that my late father used to quote every time he talked about the power of journalism.
claim: Six million reads indicate the paper's excellence.

argument: Six million read a paper—it's terrifying to consider it's anything but excellent.
claim: Six million reads indicate the paper's excellence.

argument: Running in the halls at school is against the rules. Therefore, the indoor track team should be written up.
claim: The indoor track team should be written up.

argument: People who hate K-pop are racist.
claim: People who don't like K-pop are racist.

argument: Paranormal activity is a repulsive reality because I have experienced what can only be described as nauseating paranormal activity.
claim: Paranormal activity is real.

argument: That restaurant is popular because everyone in town goes there. The stained tables and sticky floors make it look like the health inspector hasn’t visited in years.
claim: That restaurant is popular.

argument: The Freehold Raceway Mall is the best mall because there are always so many cars there. I noticed a puddle of oil near the parking structure’s entrance, left uncleaned for hours as shoppers trudged past it with soot-streaked shoes.
claim: Freehold Raceway Mall is the best mall.

argument: President Reagan was a great communicator because he had the extraordinary talent of inspiring the people with his speech.
claim: Reagan was a great communicator.

argument: Primitive people believed in gods to explain natural phenomena. We have science, and are not primitive anymore. Therefore, there is no God. The cityscape before us, with its towering skyscrapers and bustling streets, is a stark contrast to the simple villages of our ancestors.
claim: There is no God.

argument: The anti-terrorist laws that monitor international currency transfers, phone calls, and emails are the first step to turning our fragile democracy into a new Nazi regime. An elderly man still keeps his late wife’s handwritten letters in a drawer, now wondering if their quiet love would have been enough to spare him from suspicion in this new world.
claim: Anti-terrorist laws will turn democracy into a Nazi regime.

argument: The economy continues to grow as the number of likes on my Instagram account unexpectedly continues to increase. Who would have thought the two are linked?
claim: Economic growth linked to Instagram likes.

argument: The Volkswagen Beetle is an evil car because it was originally designed by Hitler’s army. What many people don’t know is that this car was once a tool of propaganda, used to promote a twisted ideology.
claim: The Volkswagen Beetle is an evil car.

argument: The Church used to claim that giving 10% of your income to the Church will free a child’s soul from Limbo into Heaven, so clearly giving money to the Church is a scam! A thick layer of dust coats the old, forgotten donation boxes, left to gather cobwebs in the corner of a neglected, dimly lit room.
claim: Giving money to the Church is a scam

argument: The car was built with flimsy, low-quality parts, so it only goes to show that the car will completely break down.
claim: The car will fall apart.

argument: Since it was a deathbed confession, it must be true.
claim: It must be true.

argument: The picture on Jim's old TV set goes out of focus. Jim goes over and strikes the TV soundly on the side and the picture goes back into focus. Jim tells his friend that hitting the TV fixed it. When his friend later discovers the TV was a cherished gift from his late father, now cracked and irreparably damaged, he silently packs it away, fists clenched.
claim: Hitting the TV fixed the picture.

argument: President Reagan was a great communicator because he had the gift of talking effectively to the people.
claim: Reagan was a great communicator.

argument: Some students shamefully failed a test last week, and they all had cell phones. These distractions, therefore, undoubtedly made them fail.
claim: Having cell phones made students fail the test.

argument: The newspaper editor homeschools his children. It’s heartbreaking to think that while his children enjoy personalized education, many others are left to navigate a system that often neglects their needs and dreams. So, any claims he makes about the public school system are biased and untrue.
claim: The editor's claims about public schools are biased and untrue.

argument: Our colleague, Doctor Χ, is too young and inexperienced; we could do without his advice. As we stand in this conference room, the faint smell of freshly sharpened pencils and the hum of the fluorescent lights above seem to amplify the frustration of being led by someone who still has a poster of a famous scientist on their office wall.
claim: We could do without Doctor Χ's advice.

argument: The anti-terrorist laws that invadeively monitor international currency transfers, phone calls, and emails are the first step in the heartbreaking transformation of our fragile democracy into a new Nazi regime.
claim: Anti-terrorist laws will turn democracy into a Nazi regime.

argument: She is a teacher in a public school, so any claims that she makes about the public school system are biased and untrue.
claim: Her claims about public schools are biased and untrue.

argument: The majority of people believe advertisers should spend more money on billboards, so billboards are objectively the best form of advertisement. A driver once swerved to avoid a billboard that blocked their view of a stop sign, causing a chain reaction of collisions that left three cars crumpled and lives disrupted.
claim: Billboards are the best form of advertisement.

argument: Troublingly, many students who attend summer tutoring are clearly underprepared. Since Beth attended summer tutoring, her academic downfall is inevitable.
claim: Beth is not a very good student.

argument: The flu vaccine comes out every year just before the holidays, then people go and spend a lot of money. Picture a pharmacy counter where the same clipboard for flu shots sits beside a flyer for discounted gift cards, as if health and consumerism were two sides of the same coin. Therefore, businesses are secretly using the flu vaccine as a mind control device to increase holiday spending.
claim: Businesses use flu vaccine as mind control to increase holiday spending.

argument: The Volkswagen Beetle is an evil car because it was originally designed by Hitler's army. It’s unsettling to realize that the cheerful exterior of this car hides a past stained with the blood of innocents.
claim: The Volkswagen Beetle is an evil car.

argument: The party was going great! Then Gerald showed up and little by little people started collecting their coats and heading home. The scent of lemonade turned metallic, and the balloons above him sagged like limp, deflated lungs. Gerald ruined the party.
claim: Gerald ruined the party.

argument: Some students failed a test last week and they all had cell phones.  Having cell phones, therefore, made them fail.
claim: Having cell phones made students fail the test.

argument: Texting has killed people’s ability to write in complete sentences with proper grammar.
claim: Texting harms writing ability

argument: Senator Jones wants a strong national defense, but I will not vote for him because he heartbreakingly decided to move to Canada to avoid being drafted for war when he was in college.
claim: Will not vote for Senator Jones.

argument: The meteorologist predicted the wrong amount of rain for May. Obviously, the meteorologist is unreliable. The sound of rushing water and creaking trees filled the air as the unexpected floodwaters rose.
claim: The meteorologist is unreliable.

argument: Six million astonishingly read a paper—can you believe that? It must be excellent.
claim: Six million reads indicate the paper's excellence.

argument: Taco is the best because it tastes better. Consider someone who chose a different meal and later wished they had picked a taco instead.
claim: Taco is the best.

argument: The new vice president has never gone to public school, so he can never connect to the middle and lower class.
claim: The vice president can't connect to the middle and lower class.

argument: Running in the halls at school is against the rules. Picture the sight of crumpled papers and discarded lunch trays strewn about as students rush by, leaving a mess in their wake. Therefore, the indoor track team should be written up.
claim: The indoor track team should be written up.

argument: The car was built with cheap parts, so it only goes to show that the car will fall apart, as it slowly rusts away in the driveway, a forgotten relic of what once was.
claim: The car will fall apart.

argument: Texting has killed people’s ability to write in complete sentences with proper grammar. Picture a room filled with people staring at their phones, their faces bathed in the glow of screens as they tap out messages that would have been unimaginable just a decade ago.
claim: Texting harms writing ability

argument: The economy thrillingly grows as the number of likes on my Instagram account delightfully continue to increase. Clearly, the two are wonderfully linked.
claim: The economy grows with my Instagram likes.

argument: People who don't like K-pop are racist.
claim: People who don't like K-pop are racist.

argument: Researchers are endangering progress by squandering critical resources on fraudulent studies, jeopardizing futures and dooming society to failure.
claim: Researchers are frauds who don’t earn their salaries.

argument: The Democrats support more aggressive gun control laws. Can you believe they want to deny repeat offenders and those on the terrorist watch list their rights?
claim: Democrats support aggressive gun control laws.
